{{redirect|Chapter Eleven|the album by Michael Lee Firkins|Chapter Eleven (album)}} {{short description|Section of the United States Bankruptcy Code}} {{update|date=April 2018}} {{USBankruptcy}}{{Insolvency}} '''Chapter 11''' is a chapter of [[Title 11 of the United States Code|Title 11]], the United States [[Bankruptcy in the United States|Bankruptcy Code]], which permits reorganization under the [[bankruptcy]] laws of the [[United States]]. Chapter 11 bankruptcy is available to every [[business]], whether organized as a [[corporation]], [[partnership]] or [[sole proprietorship]], and to individuals, although it is most prominently used by corporate entities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uscourts.gov/FederalCourts/Bankruptcy/BankruptcyBasics/Chapter11.aspx|title=Chapter 11 – Bankruptcy Basics|work=United States Courts|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> In contrast, [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7]] governs the process of a [[liquidation]] bankruptcy, though liquidation can be done under Chapter 11 also; while [[Chapter 13, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 13]] provides a reorganization process for the majority of private individuals.
==Chapter 11 overview== When a business is unable to service its debt or pay its [[creditors]], the business or its creditors can file with a [[United States bankruptcy court|federal bankruptcy court]] for protection under either Chapter 7 or Chapter 11.
In Chapter 7, the business ceases operations, a trustee sells all of its assets, and then distributes the proceeds to its creditors. Any residual amount is returned to the owners of the company.<ref name=uscourts>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uscourts.gov/services-forms/bankruptcy/bankruptcy-basics/chapter-7-bankruptcy-basics|title=Chapter 7 - Bankruptcy Basics|date=2019-03-11|website=Uscourts}}</ref>
In Chapter 11, in most instances the debtor remains in control of its business operations as a "[[debtor in possession]]", and is subject to the oversight and jurisdiction of the court.<ref name="Practitioner">Joseph Swanson and Peter Marshall, Houlihan Lokey and Lyndon Norley, Kirkland & Ellis International LLP (2008). A Practitioner's Guide to Corporate Restructuring. City & Financial Publishing, 1st edition {{ISBN|978-1-905121-31-1}}</ref>
A Chapter 11 bankruptcy will result in one of three outcomes for the debtor: reorganization, conversion to Chapter 7 bankruptcy, or dismissal.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chapter 11 - Bankruptcy Basics |url=https://www.uscourts.gov/services-forms/bankruptcy/bankruptcy-basics/chapter-11-bankruptcy-basics |website=United States Courts |accessdate=7 June 2019}}</ref> In order for a chapter 11 debtor to reorganize, the debtor must file (and the court must confirm) a plan of reorganization. In effect, the plan is a compromise between the major stakeholders in the case, including the debtor and its creditors.<ref>{{cite book |title=Commercial Bankruptcy Litigation, 2d |vauthors=Friedland JP, Vandesteeg, EB, et al |date=2019 |publisher=Thomson Reuters |location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada |isbn=978-1539233688 |pages=§10:1 |edition=2019}}</ref> Most chapter 11 cases aim to confirm a plan, but that may not always be possible.
If the judge approves the reorganization plan and the creditors all agree, then the plan can be confirmed. Section 1129 of the Bankruptcy Code requires the bankruptcy court reach certain conclusions prior to confirming or approving the plan and making it binding on all parties in the case, most notably that the plan complies with applicable law and was proposed in good faith.<ref name=uscourts/>{{USC|11|1129}} The court must also find that the reorganization plan is feasible in that, unless the plan provides otherwise, the plan is not likely to be followed by further reorganization or liquidation.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Strategic Alternatives For and Against Distressed Businesses|last=Friedland, Vandesteeg & Hammeke|first=Jonathan P., Elizabeth B., & Robert|publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]]|year=2019|isbn=978-1-539-23380-0|location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada|pages=§4:12}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Broude |first1=Richard F. |title=Cramdown and Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code: The Settlement Imperative |journal=[[The Business Lawyer]] |date=February 1984 |volume=39 |issue=2 |pages=441–454 }}</ref>
==Features of Chapter 11 reorganization== Chapter 11 retains many of the features present in all, or most, bankruptcy proceedings in the United States. It provides additional tools for debtors as well. Most importantly, {{usc|11|1108}} empowers the trustee to operate the debtor's business. In Chapter 11, unless a separate trustee is appointed for cause, the debtor, as debtor in possession, acts as trustee of the business.<ref>{{usc|11|1107}}</ref>
Chapter 11 affords the debtor in possession a number of mechanisms to restructure its business. A debtor in possession can acquire financing and loans on favorable terms by giving new lenders first priority on the business's earnings. The court may also permit the debtor in possession to reject and cancel contracts. Debtors are also protected from other litigation against the business through the imposition of an [[automatic stay]]. While the automatic stay is in place, creditors are stayed from any collection attempts or activities against the debtor in possession, and most litigation against the debtor is stayed,<ref name="law.cornell.edu">{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/11/362|title=11 U.S. Code § 362 – Automatic stay|publisher=[[Cornell University]]|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> or put on hold, until it can be resolved in bankruptcy court, or resumed in its original venue.{{cns|date=January 2019|An example of proceedings that are not necessarily stayed automatically are family law proceedings against a spouse or parent. Further, creditors may file with the court seeking relief from the automatic stay.}}
If the business is [[insolvent]], its debts exceed its assets and the business is unable to pay debts as they come due,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/ucc/1/1-201#Insolvent|title=§ 1-201. General Definitions.|publisher=|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> the bankruptcy restructuring may result in the company's owners being left with nothing; instead, the owners' rights and interests are ended and the company's creditors are left with ownership of the newly reorganized company.
All creditors are entitled to be heard by the court.<ref>1 U.S.C. Sec. 1109 (b)</ref> The court is ultimately responsible for determining whether the proposed plan of reorganization complies with bankruptcy laws.
One controversy that has broken out in bankruptcy courts concerns the proper amount of disclosure that the court and other parties are entitled to receive from the members of the creditor's committees that play a large role in many proceedings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/166ef296-0abb-11df-b35f-00144feabdc0,dwp_uuid=e8477cc4-c820-11db-b0dc-000b5df10621.html|title=Bankruptcy Rules Committee rethinks 2019 pricing disclosure amid HF panic attack|work=Financial Times|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
=== Chapter 11 plan === Chapter 11 usually results in reorganization of the debtor's business or personal assets and debts, but can also be used as a mechanism for liquidation. Debtors may "emerge" from a chapter 11 bankruptcy within a few months or within several years, depending on the size and complexity of the bankruptcy. The Bankruptcy Code accomplishes this objective through the use of a bankruptcy plan. The debtor in possession typically has the first opportunity to propose a plan during the period of exclusivity. This period allows the debtor 120 days from the date of filing for chapter 11 to propose a plan of reorganization before any other party in interest may propose a plan. If the debtor proposes a plan within the 120-day exclusivity period, a 180-day exclusivity period from the date of filing for chapter 11 is granted in order to allow the debtor to gain confirmation of the proposed plan.<ref name="law.cornell.edu" /> With some exceptions, the plan may be proposed by any party in interest.<ref>{{usc|11|1121}}</ref> Interested creditors then vote for a plan.
=== Confirmation === If the judge approves the reorganization plan and the creditors all agree, then the plan can be confirmed. If at least one class of creditors objects and votes against the plan, it may nonetheless be confirmed if the requirements of [[cramdown]] are met. In order to be confirmed over the creditors' objection, the plan must not discriminate against that class of creditors, and the plan must be found fair and equitable to that class. Upon confirmation, the plan becomes binding and identifies the treatment of debts and operations of the business for the duration of the plan. If a plan cannot be confirmed, the court may either convert the case to a liquidation under chapter 7, or, if in the best interests of the creditors and the estate, the case may be dismissed resulting in a return to the status quo before bankruptcy. If the case is dismissed, creditors will look to non-bankruptcy law in order to satisfy their claims.
In order to proceed to the confirmation hearing, a disclosure statement must be approved by the bankruptcy court.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kirkland.com/siteFiles/kirkexp/publications/2365/Document1/Friedland%20-%20Confirming%20a%20Plan.pdf|title=Confirming a Plan|last=Ayer, Bernstein & Friedland|first=John D., Michael & Jonathan P.|date=January 2015|website=DailyDAC}}</ref> Once the disclosure statement is approved, the plan proponent will solicit votes from the classes of creditors. Solicitation is the process by which creditors vote on the proposed confirmation plan. This process can be complicated if creditors fail or refuse to vote. In which case, the plan proponent might tailor his or her efforts in obtaining votes, or the plan itself.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jonesday.com/en/insights/2008/08/failure-of-creditor-class-to-cast-vote-on-chapter-11-plan-does-not-equate-to-acceptance|title=Failure of Creditor Class to Cast Vote on Chapter 11 Plan Does Not Equate to Acceptance {{!}} Insights {{!}} Jones Day|website=www.jonesday.com|language=en|access-date=2019-08-05}}</ref> The plan may be modified before confirmation, so long as the modified plan meets all the requirements of Chapter 11.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uscourts.gov/services-forms/bankruptcy/bankruptcy-basics/chapter-11-bankruptcy-basics|title=Chapter 11 – Bankruptcy Basics|website=United States Courts}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Commercial Banking Litigation|last=Friedland, Vandesteeg & Hammeke|first=Jonathan P., Elizabeth B. & Robert|publisher=Thomson Reuters|year=2019|isbn=978-1-539-23368-8|location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada|pages=§10:7}}</ref>
=== Automatic stay === Like other forms of bankruptcy, petitions filed under chapter 11 invoke the [[automatic stay]] of § 362. The automatic stay requires all creditors to cease collection attempts, and makes many post-petition debt collection efforts void or voidable. Under some circumstances, some creditors, or the [[United States Trustee]], can request the court convert the case into a liquidation under chapter 7, or appoint a trustee to manage the debtor's business. The court will grant a motion to convert to chapter 7 or appoint a trustee if either of these actions is in the best interest of all creditors. {{cns|date=January 2019|Sometimes a company will liquidate under chapter 11, in which the pre-existing management may be able to help get a higher price for divisions or other assets than a chapter 7 liquidation would be likely to achieve.}}
=== Executory contracts === {{cns|date=January 2019|Some contracts, known as [[executory contract]]s, may be rejected if canceling them would be financially favorable to the company and its creditors. Such contracts may include labor union contracts, supply or operating contracts (with both vendors and customers), and real estate leases. The standard feature of executory contracts is that each party to the contract has duties remaining under the contract. In the event of a rejection, the remaining parties to the contract become unsecured creditors of the debtor. For example, in some districts a [[contract for deed]] is an executory contract, while in others it is not.}}
In the new millennium airlines have fallen under intense scrutiny for what many see as abusing Chapter 11 bankruptcy as a tool for escaping labor contracts, usually 30-35% of an airline's operating cost.<ref>{{cite web|title=massachusetts institute of technology: Airline Data Project|url=http://web.mit.edu/airlinedata/www/Employees&Compensation.html|publisher=MIT}}</ref> Every major US airline has filed for Chapter 11 since 2002.<ref>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Richard|title=AMR Files for Bankruptcy: The Last Giant to Fall|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/business/2011/11/american-airlines-plunges-into-bankruptcy/|accessdate=19 May 2012|newspaper=ABC News|date=Nov 29, 2011}}</ref> In the space of 2 years (2002–2004) US Airways filed for bankruptcy twice<ref>{{cite news|last=Warner|first=Margeret|title=US Airways Files....Again|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/transportation/july-dec04/usairways_9-13.html|accessdate=19 May 2012|newspaper=Public Broadcasting Service|date=Sep 13, 2004}}</ref> leaving the [[AFL-CIO]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Jablonski|first=Donna|title=AFL-CIO Cries Foul|url=http://www.aflcio.org/Blog/Economy/TWU-Demands-Respect-from-American-Airlines-Bankruptcy-Court|publisher=AFL-CIO|accessdate=19 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603150718/http://www.aflcio.org/Blog/Economy/TWU-Demands-Respect-from-American-Airlines-Bankruptcy-Court|archive-date=3 June 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> pilot unions and other airline employees claiming the rules of Chapter 11 have helped turn the United States into a [[corporatocracy]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Trumbul|first=Mark|title=AMR Files for Chapter 11|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2011/1129/AMR-What-does-Chapter-11-bankruptcy-mean-for-American-Airlines-fliers|accessdate=19 May 2012|newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor|date=Nov 29, 2011}}</ref>
=== Priority === Chapter 11 follows the same priority scheme as other bankruptcy chapters. The priority structure is defined primarily by § 507 of the Bankruptcy Code ({{usc|11|507}}).
As a general rule, administrative expenses (the actual, necessary expenses of preserving the bankruptcy estate, including expenses such as employee wages, and the cost of litigating the chapter 11 case) are paid first.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/11/503|title=11 U.S. Code § 503 – Allowance of administrative expenses|publisher=|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> [[Secured creditor]]s—creditors who have a [[security interest]], or [[collateral (finance)|collateral]], in the debtor's property—will be paid before unsecured creditors. Unsecured creditors' claims are prioritized by § 507. For instance the claims of suppliers of products or employees of a company may be paid before other unsecured creditors are paid. Each priority level must be paid in full before the next lower priority level may receive payment.
=== Section 1110 === Section 1110 ({{usc|11|1110}}) generally provides a secured party with an interest in an aircraft the ability to take possession of the equipment within 60 days after a bankruptcy filing unless the airline cures all defaults. More specifically, the right of the lender to take possession of the secured equipment is not hampered by the automatic stay provisions of the Bankruptcy Code.
== Stock == If the company's stock is publicly traded, a Chapter 11 filing generally causes it to be [[delisting (stock)|delisted]] from its primary stock exchange if listed on the [[New York Stock Exchange]], the [[American Stock Exchange]], or the [[NASDAQ]]. On the NASDAQ the identifying fifth letter "Q" at the end of a stock symbol indicates the company is in bankruptcy<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/q/q.asp|title=Q Definition|last=|first=|date=|website=Investopedia|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> {{cns|date=January 2019|Many stocks that are delisted quickly resume listing as [[over-the-counter (finance)|over-the-counter]] (OTC) stocks. Actual share value does not reach zero unless the probability of restructuring is so low that a Chapter 7 filing is sure to follow.}}
{{cns|date=January 2019|Individuals may file Chapter 11, but due to the complexity and expense of the proceeding, this option is rarely chosen by debtors who are eligible for Chapter 7 or [[Chapter 13, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 13]] relief.}}
== Rationale == {{cns|date=January 2019|In enacting Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy code, Congress concluded that it is sometimes the case that the value of a business is greater if sold or reorganized as a [[going concern]] than the value of the sum of its parts if the business's assets were to be sold off individually. It follows that it may be more economically efficient to allow a troubled company to continue running, cancel some of its debts, and give ownership of the newly reorganized company to the creditors whose debts were canceled. Alternatively, the business can be sold as a going concern with the net proceeds of the sale distributed to creditors ratably in accordance with statutory priorities. In this way, jobs may be saved, the (previously mismanaged) engine of profitability which is the business is maintained (presumably under better management) rather than being dismantled, and, as a proponent of a chapter 11 plan is required to demonstrate as a precursor to plan confirmation, the business's creditors end up with more money than they would in a Chapter 7 liquidation.}}
== Considerations == {{cns|date=January 2019|The reorganization and court process may take an inordinate amount of time, limiting the chances of a successful outcome and sufficient debtor in possession financing may be unavailable during an economic recession. A preplanned, pre-agreed approach between the debtor and its creditors (sometimes called a [[prepackaged bankruptcy|pre-packaged bankruptcy]]) may facilitate the desired result. A company undergoing Chapter 11 reorganization is effectively operating under the "protection" of the court until it emerges.}} An example is the [[airline industry]] in the United States; in 2006 over half the industry's [[seating capacity]] was on airlines that were in Chapter 11.<ref>{{cite news | title = Delta and Northwest airlines both file for bankruptcy | url = http://money.cnn.com/2005/09/14/news/fortune500/bankruptcy_airlines/ | accessdate = November 17, 2005 | work=CNN | date=2005-09-14 | first1=Chris | last1=Isidore | first2=/Money | last2=Senior}}</ref> These airlines were able to stop making debt payments, break their previously agreed upon labor union contracts, freeing up cash to expand routes or weather a price war against competitors — all with the bankruptcy court's approval.
Studies on the impact of forestalling the creditors' rights to enforce their security reach different conclusions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.economist.com/displaystory.cfm?story_id=1494270|title=The night of the killer zombies|work=Economist.com|date=2002-12-12|accessdate=2006-08-05}}</ref>
== Deadlines == Within 60 days of filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, the debtor must submit a written disclosure statement with the court containing information on assets, liabilities and business affairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dcdmlawgroup.com/2014/02/3-deadlines-beware-filing-chapter-11-bankruptcy/|title=3 Deadlines to Beware of When Filing a Chapter 11 Bankruptcy|work=DCDM|date=2014-02-17|accessdate=2014-10-15}}</ref>
== Statistics == {{See also|Category:Companies that have filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy}}
=== Frequency === Chapter 11 cases dropped by 60% from 1991 to 2003. One 2007 study<ref name="WSJSpurn">(January 24, 2007), "Small Firms Spurn Chapter 11", ''Wall Street Journal'', page B6B</ref> found this was because businesses were turning to bankruptcy-like proceedings under state law, rather than the federal bankruptcy proceedings, including those under chapter 11. Insolvency proceedings under state law, the study stated, are currently faster, less expensive, and more private, with some states not even requiring court filings. However, a 2005 study<ref name="WSJSpurn" /> claimed the drop may have been due to an increase in the incorrect classification of many bankruptcies as "consumer cases" rather than "business cases".
{{cns|date=January 2019|Cases involving more than US$50 million in assets are almost always handled in federal bankruptcy court, and not in bankruptcy-like state proceeding.}}
